verses.text: When the LORD was about to take Elijah up to heaven by a whirlwind, Elijah and Elisha were traveling from Gilgal.
verses.comment: Retains reference to Elijah's supernatural departure and the journey origin.

verses.text: Elijah said to Elisha, 'Stay here, for the LORD has sent me as far as Bethel.' But Elisha replied, 'As the LORD lives and as you yourself live, I will not leave you.' So they went down to Bethel.
verses.comment: Preserves Elisha's loyalty and Elijah's travel to Bethel.

verses.text: The sons of the prophets who were at Bethel came out to Elisha and asked him, 'Do you know that today the LORD will take your master away from you?' He answered, 'Yes, I know; be silent.'
verses.comment: Maintains the phrase 'sons of the prophets'; 'be silent' as a command for quietness.

verses.text: Then Elijah said to him, 'Elisha, stay here, because the LORD has sent me to Jericho.' But he said, 'As the LORD lives and as you yourself live, I will not leave you.' So they came to Jericho.
verses.comment: Repeats Elisha’s vow; follows the sequence from Bethel to Jericho.

verses.text: The sons of the prophets who were at Jericho approached Elisha and said, 'Do you know that today the LORD will take your master away from you?' He replied, 'Yes, I know; be silent.'
verses.comment: Almost verbatim repeat from verse 3 for continuity.

verses.text: Elijah said to him, 'Stay here, because the LORD has sent me to the Jordan.' But he said, 'As the LORD lives and as you yourself live, I will not leave you.' So both of them went on.
verses.comment: Follows the repetitive pattern; Jordan as final destination.

verses.text: Fifty men of the sons of the prophets went and stood at some distance, facing them as they both stood by the Jordan.
verses.comment: Number specified, location clarified.

verses.text: Then Elijah took his cloak, rolled it up, and struck the water. The water was divided to one side and to the other, so they both crossed over on dry ground.
verses.comment: Miraculous crossing; 'divided to one side and to the other' kept literal.

verses.text: When they had crossed over, Elijah said to Elisha, 'Ask what I shall do for you before I am taken from you.' And Elisha said, 'Please let there be a double portion of your spirit upon me.'
verses.comment: ‘Double portion’ retains inheritance language from Hebrew.

verses.text: He replied, 'You have asked a difficult thing. If you see me when I am taken from you, it shall be yours; but if you do not see me, it shall not be so.'
verses.comment: Faithful to the conditional promise in the original.

verses.text: As they were walking and talking together, suddenly a chariot of fire with horses of fire appeared and separated the two of them, and Elijah went up by a whirlwind into heaven.
verses.comment: ‘Chariot and horses of fire’ literal; ‘heaven’ as sky or God's presence.

verses.text: Elisha saw it and cried out, 'My father, my father! The chariots of Israel and its horsemen!' Then he saw Elijah no more. He grabbed his own clothes and tore them in two.
verses.comment: ‘My father’ is an honorific title; tearing clothes is sign of mourning.

verses.text: Elisha picked up Elijah's cloak that had fallen from him, and he returned and stood on the bank of the Jordan.
verses.comment: ‘Cloak’ symbolizes prophetic succession.

verses.text: He took Elijah's cloak and struck the waters, saying, 'Where is the LORD, the God of Elijah?' And when he struck the water, it was divided to one side and to the other, and Elisha crossed over.
verses.comment: Echoes Elijah’s miracle; Elisha invokes God’s power.

verses.text: When the sons of the prophets who were at Jericho saw him from a distance, they said, 'The spirit of Elijah rests on Elisha.' And they went to meet him and bowed to the ground before him.
verses.comment: ‘Spirit of Elijah’ means his prophetic calling.

verses.text: They said to him, 'Look, there are fifty strong men among your servants. Let them go and seek your master, perhaps the Spirit of the LORD has lifted him up and set him on some mountain or in some valley.' He replied, 'Do not send them.'
verses.comment: ‘Spirit of the LORD’ understood as supernatural transport.

verses.text: But when they urged him until he was embarrassed, he said, 'Send them.' So they sent fifty men, who searched for three days but did not find him.
verses.comment: 'Embarrassed' translates idiom of being put to shame or pressured.

verses.text: When they returned to him at Jericho where he was staying, he said to them, 'Did I not say to you, do not go?'
verses.comment: Elisha’s rebuke preserved as rhetorical question.

verses.text: The men of the city said to Elisha, 'Look, the location of this city is good, as my lord sees, but the water is bad and the land is unproductive.'
verses.comment: ‘Unproductive’ translates Hebrew for miscarrying or barren.

verses.text: He said, 'Bring me a new bowl and put salt in it.' So they brought it to him.
verses.comment: ‘Salt’ is the instrument for the miracle.

verses.text: Then he went to the spring of water and threw the salt in it, and said, 'Thus says the LORD: I have healed this water. From now on it will neither cause death nor make the land unfruitful.'
verses.comment: ‘Healed’ clarifies the effect of the miracle; ‘neither cause death’ is literal.

verses.text: So the water has been healed to this day, according to the word that Elisha spoke.
verses.comment: ‘To this day’ indicates ongoing effect.

verses.text: Afterward he went up from there to Bethel. As he was traveling up the road, some young boys came out from the city and mocked him, saying, 'Go up, baldhead! Go up, baldhead!'
verses.comment: ‘Young boys’ literal; ‘baldhead’ as insult, retained for clarity.

verses.text: When he turned around and saw them, he cursed them in the name of the LORD. Then two female bears came out of the woods and mauled forty-two of the boys.
verses.comment: ‘Mauled’ conveys violent attack; numbers kept literal.

verses.text: From there he went to Mount Carmel and then he returned to Samaria.
verses.comment: Mount Carmel and Samaria are retained as geographical markers.
